According to Al Nogen, president of the BIA, "The BIA is
better set to coordinate athletic
activities; it has the necessary
organizational experience. The
best thing was for the BIA to
take over the leagues of the
DSRC."
Additional Plans
Additional plans announced by
Nogen have been geared to make
the intramural activities more
interesting. Two All-Star teams,
one from the independent teams
and • one from the fraternity
teams, will be chosen for each
of the major sports. Also, an
award will be presented in each
of the major sports to the outstanding athlete.

Meanwhile, at the Republican

In contrast to this scene the
News-Letter reporter at the
Emerson saw Dr. Clarence Long,
professor of economics at JHU,
as a barometer of Democratic
emotions. Early in the evening
Dr. Long refused to make any
predictions, but as the evening
-wore on he was more willing
to "stick out his neck."
Quiet Sun
In contrast to these scenes of
controlled elation and quiet depression, the Sun Paper's city
room was quiet and "efficient
as a machine. Everybody
milled around and then all of
a sudden the results went up.
They looked like it was old hat
to them. Not one person came
running into the room in his
shirt sieves yelling 'stop the
presses!"
The general consensus of the
five News Letter reporters and
the two photographers out covering the elections was that it
was too quiet. As one reporter
put it, "Nobody was really excited. It was almost as if nothing was happening. Everybody

about it. I kept waiting for the
shouting and excitement one
usually associates with a presidential election but it never
occurred.

the climb up to the fourth floor of Gilman Hall.
there awaits an abundance of information in the
field of economics, political science and related
subjects. For there nestled snugly between the
rows of professors offices which line the fourth
floor of Gilman Hall is the Documents library.

literally all of the periodical information pertaining to the functions and daily proceedings

tioned. The JHU Press had its
beginnings in 1878 when Daniel
Coit Gilman established a publication agency to print the
American Journal of Mathematics. In 1890 the Johns Hopkins
Press was formally established.
The Hopkins Press has quadrupled it size since 1948. According to Harold E. Ingle, director of the Press, books sales
have increased 26% in the past
year. Paperback rights to some
17 Press books have been sold to
such firms as Doubleday, Knopf,
Bantam, and Harper. Bantam is
currently planning a 90,000 copy
first run of the Press's current
best seller, The Seven Ages of
Woman by Dr. Elizabeth Parker.
Scholarly Works
The Hopkins Press, like all
scholarly presses, is devoted to
the publishing of non-fiction

scholarly works which have been
developed in response to the
needs of scholars. The Press is
a non-profit organization and
aims not at popularity but fulfilling the need of scholars
throughout the world for technical books on specialized subjects.
The average first run edition
of a book published by the Hopkins Press is 2-3,000 copies. The
all time best-seller of the Press

is Numerical Mathematical
Analysis by James B. Scarborough, which was first published in the '30's and has since
sold some 40,000 copies.

Advanced data processing systems—whether designed
for business, industry, science, or government—have
been made possible by the talents and abilities of the
mathematician.
Harold Mechanic, for instance, is working in areas of
system simulation. He and his colleagues have done
some of their most interesting work in building mathematical models to study the performance of proposed
Tele-Processing* systems. After transforming the models
into computer language, numerous possible system configurations were fed into a giant computer to determine
an optimum arrangement of components.Thus, like many
mathematicians at IBM, Harold Mechanic is able to use
the computer as a tool to advance both theory and technique of systems analysis.

If you are receiving your degree in mathematics, you
might do well to investigate the unusual opportunities at
IBM. Working alone, or as a member of a small team, you
will find many chances to make important contributions
to your field. You will also be eligible for excellent education programs.
Positions will be open in mathematics research, computer
programming, and applied mathematics. The IBM representative will be interviewing on your campus. tie will be
glad to give you further information. Your placement
office can make an appointment. Or you may write, outlining your background and interests, to:

Report Considered
The report of the committee investigating the SAC
has been released and has turned out to be nothing more
than a reaffirmation of the present set-up. Not changed
is the 2.3 rule and waiver; not changed is the self-perpetuating aspect of the SAC found so questionable by the
Student-Faculty Camp.
Since the report has not been accepted we feel there
is still time for a few comments and suggestions.
There is no point in rehashing the problems of the
,
and the waiver rule, powers for the enforceaverage
2.3
ment of which are granted to the SAC. We believe the 2.3
is too high and the waiver rules leaves too much power in
the hands of too small a group. We would .support a 2.0
average requirement with no wavers.
On the self-perpetuating aspect, we must remind the
Council that the SAC is a committee under the SC's jurisdiction. Yet it has been allowed to become practically
autonomous through its power over the finances and elections of other Hopkins organizations, detracting greatly
from the influence and prestige of the Student Council.
The SAC consists of five men, including a chairman
chosen by the graduating seniors of the Commission. The
other four are chosen by the seniors and the prospective
chairman. The Student Council may review the men
chosen but has a difficult job since it does not review the
other men considered.
Thus, in effect, the SAC perpetuates itself, leaving
the Council with little to say as to its members.
'We feel there is an alternative to the present procedure—one which would put the SAC definitely subordinate to the Student Council, yet give it that freedom from
school politics it needs to function. We suggest that the
Student Council President appoint from among the newly
elected council members the new SAC Chairman. He, with
the retiring seniors on the SAC, would then, interview
prospective members.
This solution would both preeminate the Student
Council and preserve the effectiveness of the Student
Activities Commission.

H-H Coordination
While the 'BIA-DSRC athletic problem may seem
trivial to many, it does shine some light on the eternal
controversy of who should control what at the Homewood.
There is so much duplication and parallelism amongst the
'planning and acting' organizations, and it is so well
known among campus leaders, that the action taken by
the BIA, which is the Board of Intramural Athletics, could
very well be a guidepost for greater inter-organization
relations. Instead of half a dozen organizations planning
social activities and conflicting with each other, let the
Cotillion Board, as it has been trying to do, act as a sort
of clearing house for dates and types of functions. Maintain the Student Council as a student government body
and let it divert problems not pertaining to its functions
to the DSRC, the Booster Club, the IFC or whichever
organization is best set up and coordinated to handle it.
This may all sound a bit idealistic, but how much
effort does it take to channel a problem from, say, the SC
to the DSRC ... a phone call or a note in a mail box?
We've got ourselves a functioning Goucher-Hopkins
Coordination Committee; maybe we could use a functioning Hopkins-Hopkins Coordination Committee.

Awareness
The grand coverage that the News-Letter has afforded
to the presidential cappaign is an unusual exception to
our policy of not attempting to cover and' print international, national, or even local news unless it has some connection with the Hopkins Institutions and would be of
general interest to all its readers.
'Because of a noticeable lack of organized campus
political activity, but with (we hope) a lot of individual
interest in the campaigns and their outcome, we thought
that the NeWs-Letter might do well to inform its interested readers about the behind-the- scenes hustle and
bustle on election night at various important spots around
Baltimore.
This election that brought John F. Kennedy to the
'position of President-elect was the closest presidential
campaign since 1880. Perhaps by understanding what
really went on on election eve, we might be able to instill
a bit more political awareness in a few more students.
Isn't this certainly a part of a well-rounded college education?

Literary Club Stimulates Interest
Though few people realize it, the Tudor and
Stuart Club is perhaps the only organization on
campus which costs members nothing, yet gives
a great deal in return.
The club's activities are numerous, including
meetings for the exchange of ideas among all
levels and schools of the University, the sponsorship of three contests with money prizes, and
the maintenance of an extremely fine collection
of rare books.
Members pay no dues and are not required to
participate in anything if they do not wish to..
They do, however, benefit from several things.
First are the monthly meetings. These consist
of a lecture on a special subject by a mem-

ber or invited speaker followed by discussion and refreshments. The meetings are
held in the club's own beautifully decorated
rooms on the third floor of Gilman Hall. The
rooms are open only to members and are a perfect place for study or for research.
Awards
Another important activity is the awarding
of three prizes to stimulate interest in literature
among undergraduates. The prizes are: $40 for
the best research essay dealing with some aspect
of English cultural history, $40 for the best
effort in creative writing, and $20 for the most
intelligently and carefully planned student library. All undergraduates are eligible and should
hand in entries by a tentative deadline of March
1; 1961. For further information, Dr. John Walton, chairman of the Education Department and
president of the club, should be consulted.
Finally, the club maintains a collection of
rare books, among which is one of the best collections of Spenser in existence. Many of the
books are on shelves in the club room, but the
more valuable ones are kept in a large safe.
Club Origin
The club was founded and endowed by Sir
William and Lady Osler in 1918,,in memory of
their son, Edward Revere Osler, and to stimulate interest in the Tudor and Stuart periods of
English Literature. The Osler family contributed
the money for the endowment and for the book
collection, while a friend, Mrs. William Brewster, contributed money to build the club room.
Membership in the Club is open to any faculty member, graduate, undergraduate, or friend
of the University recommended by a member.
Dr. Walton feels that the club is "an excellent chance for students to engage in what
might be called very plasant extra-curricular
activity, and provides an interest which ought
to be encouraged among graduates and under-.
graduates."

A MODEST PROPOSAL
A movement is afoot—a shocking, startling movement—to
solve the problem of overcrowded colleges by the simple expedient of refusing admission to women at coeducational schools!
It is argued by proponents of this plan that in today's world
a college education is absolutely essential for a man, while for
a woman it is merely a pleasant interlude between adolescence
and housewifery. There is simply not room enough for both men
and women in our overburdened colleges; therefore, in all fairness, women who have farless need of a degree than men, must
Yield their places.
Well sir, when I heard this drastic proposal,I was so shocked
that Isat right down and lit a Marlboro. I always sit right down
and light a Marlboro when Jam shocked. I also always sit right
down and light a Marlboro when I am not shocked. There is
no time, no condition, no mood, no estate when it isn't a source
of soul-deep gratification to settle back and have a full-flavored
smoke—Marlboro,the filtered cigarette with the unfiltered taste
— Marlboro, the jewel of cigarettes—Marlboro, the pinnacle of
the tobacconist's art—Marlboro, my comfort, haven, and snug
harbor.
Well sir, I sat smoking my Marlboro and thinking over the
shocking proposal to keep women out of coed schools,and hoping
fervently that another solution can be found. If the calamitous
(lay ever comes when women are banned from coed colleges, I
Will gnash my teeth and rend my garments and take to my bed
Without supper. Like any other Marlboro man,I love women.
I love the sight and sound of them, the cut of their jibs, their
beauty and grace, their cunning little spitcurls, their sleek
dimples, their middy blouses, their aura and effluvium. Moreover, I freely admit that when it comes to brainpower, they can
give the average man cards and spades and big casino too. It
would be a shame, a disgrace and a catastrophe to keep these
beautiful, intelligent creatures out of college.
However, it is always wise in time of fair weather to prepare
for foul. What if the advocates of keeping women out of college
begin to gather strength? We who abhor this fiendish plan must
be ready with a substitute...and it just so happens I have
one—and a mighty ingenious little plan it is, if I say so myself.
Granted that classroom seats are in short supply,and granted
that men need degrees more than women,it is still not necessary
to bar women from college. Let them go to college but—here is
the beauty part of my plan—don't let them go to class!

JACK SAVED HIS COMPANY $10,000
ON HIS FIRST ASSIGNMENT
While Jack Trabert was in college he had
some definite career ideas. He knew what he
wanted—a job with a payoff for good judgment
and hard work.
With a B.S. in Business Administration from
the University of Nebraska, Jack knew he could
look in many directions. And he did. He talked
to 20 companies. And then in August, 1957,
joined Northwestern Bell, in Omaha, Nebraska.
His chance to show what he could do was
not long in coming. On his first assignment Jack
came up with answers that made it possible to
handle long distance calls made at night in the
Omaha area with less force and equipment than
was needed under the old system. This resulted
in a $10,000 annual saving.
•
Next, Jack worked on a training and devel-

opment program for "mark sensing"—a new
method for mechanized processing of long distance charges.
Today, Jack has an important role in planning and developing telephone facilities to keep
pace with Omaha's ever-increasing need for long
distance services.
Jack puts it this way—"If a guy can keep
his average up, there are places to go in this
outfit. A man doesn't have to wait around for
opportunity to knock—he has all he can handle
right from the start."
If you want a job in which you're given a chance
to show your stuff, and held strictly accountable for
your decisions, right from the start—then you'll
want to visit your Placement Office for literature
and additional information.

By MATT CRENSON
The Emerson Hotel's WJZ-TV
headquarters was not exactly a
beehive of political activity last
Tuesday night as the television
station's personnel far outnumbered political partisans for a
good part of the evening. The
mood of those Democrats who
were present changed from one
of optimistic expectancy, to pressimism, to calm assurance.
Underlying the changes in temperament was a type of indifference characteristic of the Free

State.
Johns Hopkins' own Dr: Clarence Long, professor of political
economy and sometime candidate for the U.S. Senate, was
on hand to analyze the election
returns as they were received
over UPI teletype machines. Dr.
Long was at first reluctant to
make any definite predictions,
but as the night wore on and
the number of Democratic supporters on the premises become
greater, he grew more confident
in his prognostications. Dr. Long
gave Kennedy the election and
Predicted that the Democrats be
victorious in all state Congressional races except for the one
in the 6th district.
Among the onlookers in the
Emerson ballroom were two
gentlemen from the New Delhi
Medical School who seemed puzzled at the place of electronic
brains and the chattering teletype machines in the democratic
process. They compared the
quick coverage of the presidential race in the United States
with Indian elections in which
final results are sometimes not
politicos available for months.

Jays Vs. Devils In IVLA Homestretch

Saturday's Game
Seen Is A Must
For Title Hopes
The Johns Hopkins soccer
team upped its season record to
672 during the last week in
games against the Shoremen of
Washington College, and the
Terrapins of Maryland.
In a game played last Saturday at Homewood, the Blue met
Washington College, possessors
01 a 6-3 record for the Fall.
Hopkins entered the game with
a 5-1 slate and the knowledge
that they must win to keep their
hopes alive for victory in the
Middle Atlantic Southern Division,
,The • weather was cold, and
gray, and that is the way the
game looked from the opening
Whistle. A slow starting team
all season, the Jays for once
reversed the trend and started
fast. Dominating the game for
Much of the first half; the Homewoodians kept control of the
ball and worked it around to set
up their scoring thrusts. Twice
in the first two quarters Hopkins players missed good chances,
and were forced to leave the
field at halftime in a 0-0 tie.
Fear of Washington's_ proven
comeback ability was in the air
at the start of the second-half,
and the drizzle that was falling
had everybody leery as the ball
Slithered merrily around the
field. Hopkins was imbued with
the will to win, however, and
Just before the end of the third
quarter Don Evenson scored unassisted. Going into the fourth
quarter the Blue led, 1-0.

Jays' Winning Wedge
Wrecks Swarthmore ,
By IRV NATHAN, Ass't Sports Editor
The "big-time" college athlete, particularly the football
player, is a strange breed.
He is usually maligned as being a dunce, majoring
in basketweaving, accepted (or bought) by the school to
bring fame and fortune to the institution. He is depicted
as being only a little short of a paid professional and is
usually thought of as being the beneficiary of both large
and small favors from professors, administrators, and
fellow students.
He is delineated as a mammoth brute hardly able to
pronounce the name of the university. He is the brunt of
rumors concerning such illegal practices as "red-shirting"
(playing for more than four years) and bribery.
In short, he is not even considered a student, but
rather a pariah who is well-reimbursed for his services.
At Hopkins, a "small-time" grid school, a footballplaying student iS not the recipient of special favors
and there are few, if any, rumors circulated, because no
one talks about him. The question at hand, then, is why
do these twenty-eight bruisers spend every week-day
afternoon knocking heads, and every Saturday defending
the well-deserved titles they captured last season.
Loyalty and a sense of deep pride are the prime
ingredients for a well-knit squad, and the Blue Jay varsity
pigskinners are a well-knit squad. Statistics- produced in
a recent issue of Sports Illustrated proved that college
athletes were receiving slightly better positions in the
business world than their merely academic classmates. It
is the considered opinion here that this loyalty and pride
are aslo fundamental requisites for success with any firm
or organization. And these devoted boys have this pride
and loyalty for the team and for the Johns Hopkins Universal.
It looked like Maryland was just too good for them
but despite the lopsided score the Varsity Soccermen
hung in all the way. They fought hard and hustled to the
last minute. Maryland had to work hard for those goals
and there were probably plenty terrapins rubbing their
black and blue marks on the way home.

Johns Hopkins varsity football
contingent, fresh from a convincing conquest of Swarthmore
last week, will entertain Mid-Atlantic opponent Dickinson in the
last home game of the campaign
tomorrow afternoon.
With the inside track on the
southern part of the Middle-atlantic championship, the Blue
Jay gridders face two must
games, this one and the encounter with Western Maryland
one week hence.
Dickinson comes in with an
unimpressive record for this
Homecoming weekend, but most
grid mentors will tell you it's
these "lowly" teams that bring
off the biggest upsets and spoil
the dreams of many a title contender.
Though the Red Devils have
posted but a 1-5 record for the
season, they boast backfield experience and the depth which the
Jays lack. Hopkins will outweigh
their Pennsylvania opponent by
five pounds down the line but
the likes of Center Don Fields
and Tackle Jim Wagner should
provide a stern test for the Jay
forward wall.
Running out of a varied offense off a split "T" formation,
Dickinson should have its major
problem in the line where they
will be missing the services of
Tackle Dave Morrissey, who was
a real "headache" for Hopkins in
the clash last year.
Last Saturday, the Jays bested
a determined Swarthmore aggregation to the tune of 21-12.
Using only five plays, primarily
a fullback wedge, the Jays ran
over and through Garnet lineman, running its seasonal log to
5-1-1.
Unbeaten and united in Middle-Atlantic competition, the
Jays are one-half game ahead of
Pennsylvania Military College
who are presently sporting a
5-1-0 mark. In the two conference games remaining, PMC

will go up against winless
Swarthmore and power-laden
Lebanon Valley. Though very
deep and powerful, the Lebanon
Valley gridders just eeked out
a win over Hopkins' for Dickinson, earlier in the year.
Following PMC in the southern
division are Ursinus (3:3-0),
Western
Maryland
(1-2-0),
Dickinson (1-4-0), Swarthmore
(0-3-0), Drexel (0-5-0), and
Haverford (0-5-0). Ineligible for
the league crown are Franklin
and Marshall (1-1-0) and West
Chester (no games).
Jay Coach Wilson Fewster
lauded all the gridders for what
he called "a real outstanding
team effort" in the Swarthmore
battle. He added that it has been
this attidue of playing for the
team and not for themselves that
has garnered the impressive record the Jays have accumulated.
A large Homecoming crowd is
expected to be on hand for the
2:00 kickoff. Another large turnout is anticipated for the Western Maryland game next week.

Hopkins varsity crosscountry
squad, harried last week by an
elusive track, will seek again to
run the "straight and narrow"
tomorrow when it encounters
Pennsylvania Military College
and Elizabeth won here.
A grueling four-and-a-half
mile Swarthmore course proved
to be too much for the Hopkins
harriers last Saturday, as the
hill 'n' 'dalers were defeated by
the Garnet runners, 22-37., Lack
of luck and team depth, mostly
the latter, were responsible for
Hopkins' second loss.
Lady luck played its role when
it separated Jay runner Don
Smilovitz from the rest of the
ensuing pack. Smilovitz, leading
the field at this point, turned
mistakenly off the course. Before
he realized his miscalculation,
five men had passed him, four
of .them from Swarthmore.
The winner of the race was

Hopkins' Jim Fitzpatrick, long

to
playing
the

at 25:58. Next best for Hopkins
was Smilovitz in sixth place,
followed by Jay thinclad Steve
Haust. However, the four runners wedged between Fitzpatrick
proved more than enough to insure the Swarthmore victory.
Harrier Coach George Brown
expects stiffer competition from
PMC in tomorrow's race which
should serve as a tune-up for

Looking ahead to the Masonexpects

Dixon
Hopkins to enter the race as cofavorites with host Bridgewater

Tomorrow's two-thirty encounter will be the culmination

season. The varsity crosscountrymen have posted a 5-2 log and

State, Franklin and Marshall
College, Gettysburg and Washington (a triangular meet),

Frosh Basketball
Thursday, November 17th,
at 4 P.M., in the weight room
of the gymnasium, there will
be an organizational meeting
of all freshmen interested in
playing intercollegiate basketball. Mr. Scott is the freshman basketball coach.

After starting the year off with
a "big bang," the Hopkins varsity rifle team journeys to Gettysburg College this afternoon to
shoot it out with the Bullets this
afternoon.
The riflemen opened their season with a resounding win over
Delaware last Friday. The Blue
Jays fired a 1378 out of possible
1500, 19 points higher than any
of last year's scores. The Delaware team shot a 1276.
Team captain John Belt was
JHU's top scorer with a 96-93-92,
for a total Of 281. Also scoring
strongly for the Blue Jays were
Gordon Hair with a 279, Dan
Searing shooting 277, Carl Born
with a 272, and Tito del Amo,
who shot 269. Bob Steinhauer,
first for the University, of Delaware, shot a 261.
Following the match with Gettysburg, the rifle team will host
Morgan State Teachers College,
Friday, November 18. Also in addition to its regular schedule, the
riflemen will aim their barrels in
an attempt to bag the Hearst
Trophy.

Frosh Footballers End Maryland Swamps Soccermen
Season Vs.Gettysburg For 1st Jay Shutout In 2 Years
By TED PARLETTE
Today, the freshmen football
season for Hopkins comes to an
end with the yearling Jays taking on Gettysburg College across
the border in Pennsylvania. After
a very fine job last week in holding a big B.J.C. group to only
two touchdowns, the team has
an even bigger task cut out for
them this week.
In containing B.J.C.'s powerful
single-wing attack, Hopkins allowed but two touchdowns via
the ground route, the other two
coming as opportunity plays on
a kickoff and a poor punt. Two
Of these TDs were called back
because of penalties against
B.J.C., however. Bearing special
notice on defense were Steve
Erlanger who was outstanding
as a defensive end, and Joe Hahn
and Chuck Aronhalt who shared
top tackle honors with 5 apiece.
The rest of the forward wall
also deserves a vote of confidence
for their part in containing their
Much bigger and heavier opponents.
Directing the offense, which
gained more yardage than in

any previous outing this year,
was quarterback Tom Tropp.
Rushing, Hopkins piled up 104
yards to Baltimore Junior College's 172. A large part of this
yardage, in fact 56 yards of it,
belonged to halfback John Heller
who averaged 5.6 yards per carry. Fullback Walt Divers was
second with an average of 3.5'
It was a good day all around for
the freshman team.
Gettysburg, while not so big as
B.J.C., is undoubtedly a stronger
team, having the experience of
13 high school captains or cocaptains on their squad. In the
past two seasons.at Hopkins, the
frosh footballers have lost only
One game each. Both of these
have been to Gettysburg outfits
like this year's. This suffices to
show it's going to be a tough
game, especially for Hopkins.
There were several odd punt
plays in the game, both involving
kicker Chuck Aronhalt. In the
first of these, a short kick was
caught by the wind and blown
back to the home five-yard line
where a Baltimore Junior College
lineman scooped it up and carried the pigskin to pay dirt.

(Continued from Page 9)
The last quarter was a fingernail biter all the way as first
the Jays, and then Washington,
fired away at each others' goalies.
Bob Keane, JHU netminder, successfully repulsed all W.C. scoring efforts and Hopkins won its
second shutout in a row.

deflated Hopkins hope of pulling off one of the upsets of the
year. Scoring in every period,
and with inside right Cliff Krug
netting five, the Marylanders
controlled the game throughout,

and at will.
With two games remaining,
against Drexel here on Saturday
at noon, and Western Maryland
away Nov. 19, the Bluejays still
have an outside chance for the
Middle Atlantic Southern crown.

The victory over Washington
lifted the Jays Middle Atlantic
mark to 4-1, with two games remaining. Hopkins is undefeated
in Mason-Dixon play, with a 3-0
mark, but are ineligible for the
title as they do not play enough
games.

Report Considered
The report of the committee investigating the SAC
has been released and has turned out to be nothing more
than a reaffirmation of the present set-up. Not changed
is the 2.3 rule and waiver; not changed is the self-perpetuating aspect of the SAC found so questionable by the
Student-Faculty Camp.
Since the report has not been accepted we feel there
is still time for a few comments and suggestions.
There is no point in rehashing the problems of the
,
and the waiver rule, powers for the enforceaverage
2.3
ment of which are granted to the SAC. We believe the 2.3
is too high and the waiver rules leaves too much power in
the hands of too small a group. We would .support a 2.0
average requirement with no wavers.
On the self-perpetuating aspect, we must remind the
Council that the SAC is a committee under the SC's jurisdiction. Yet it has been allowed to become practically
autonomous through its power over the finances and elections of other Hopkins organizations, detracting greatly
from the influence and prestige of the Student Council.
The SAC consists of five men, including a chairman
chosen by the graduating seniors of the Commission. The
other four are chosen by the seniors and the prospective
chairman. The Student Council may review the men
chosen but has a difficult job since it does not review the
other men considered.
Thus, in effect, the SAC perpetuates itself, leaving
the Council with little to say as to its members.
'We feel there is an alternative to the present procedure—one which would put the SAC definitely subordinate to the Student Council, yet give it that freedom from
school politics it needs to function. We suggest that the
Student Council President appoint from among the newly
elected council members the new SAC Chairman. He, with
the retiring seniors on the SAC, would then, interview
prospective members.
This solution would both preeminate the Student
Council and preserve the effectiveness of the Student
Activities Commission.

H-H Coordination
While the 'BIA-DSRC athletic problem may seem
trivial to many, it does shine some light on the eternal
controversy of who should control what at the Homewood.
There is so much duplication and parallelism amongst the
'planning and acting' organizations, and it is so well
known among campus leaders, that the action taken by
the BIA, which is the Board of Intramural Athletics, could
very well be a guidepost for greater inter-organization
relations. Instead of half a dozen organizations planning
social activities and conflicting with each other, let the
Cotillion Board, as it has been trying to do, act as a sort
of clearing house for dates and types of functions. Maintain the Student Council as a student government body
and let it divert problems not pertaining to its functions
to the DSRC, the Booster Club, the IFC or whichever
organization is best set up and coordinated to handle it.
This may all sound a bit idealistic, but how much
effort does it take to channel a problem from, say, the SC
to the DSRC ... a phone call or a note in a mail box?
We've got ourselves a functioning Goucher-Hopkins
Coordination Committee; maybe we could use a functioning Hopkins-Hopkins Coordination Committee.

Awareness
The grand coverage that the News-Letter has afforded
to the presidential cappaign is an unusual exception to
our policy of not attempting to cover and' print international, national, or even local news unless it has some connection with the Hopkins Institutions and would be of
general interest to all its readers.
'Because of a noticeable lack of organized campus
political activity, but with (we hope) a lot of individual
interest in the campaigns and their outcome, we thought
that the NeWs-Letter might do well to inform its interested readers about the behind-the- scenes hustle and
bustle on election night at various important spots around
Baltimore.
This election that brought John F. Kennedy to the
'position of President-elect was the closest presidential
campaign since 1880. Perhaps by understanding what
really went on on election eve, we might be able to instill
a bit more political awareness in a few more students.
Isn't this certainly a part of a well-rounded college education?

Literary Club Stimulates Interest
Though few people realize it, the Tudor and
Stuart Club is perhaps the only organization on
campus which costs members nothing, yet gives
a great deal in return.
The club's activities are numerous, including
meetings for the exchange of ideas among all
levels and schools of the University, the sponsorship of three contests with money prizes, and
the maintenance of an extremely fine collection
of rare books.
Members pay no dues and are not required to
participate in anything if they do not wish to..
They do, however, benefit from several things.
First are the monthly meetings. These consist
of a lecture on a special subject by a mem-

ber or invited speaker followed by discussion and refreshments. The meetings are
held in the club's own beautifully decorated
rooms on the third floor of Gilman Hall. The
rooms are open only to members and are a perfect place for study or for research.
Awards
Another important activity is the awarding
of three prizes to stimulate interest in literature
among undergraduates. The prizes are: $40 for
the best research essay dealing with some aspect
of English cultural history, $40 for the best
effort in creative writing, and $20 for the most
intelligently and carefully planned student library. All undergraduates are eligible and should
hand in entries by a tentative deadline of March
1; 1961. For further information, Dr. John Walton, chairman of the Education Department and
president of the club, should be consulted.
Finally, the club maintains a collection of
rare books, among which is one of the best collections of Spenser in existence. Many of the
books are on shelves in the club room, but the
more valuable ones are kept in a large safe.
Club Origin
The club was founded and endowed by Sir
William and Lady Osler in 1918,,in memory of
their son, Edward Revere Osler, and to stimulate interest in the Tudor and Stuart periods of
English Literature. The Osler family contributed
the money for the endowment and for the book
collection, while a friend, Mrs. William Brewster, contributed money to build the club room.
Membership in the Club is open to any faculty member, graduate, undergraduate, or friend
of the University recommended by a member.
Dr. Walton feels that the club is "an excellent chance for students to engage in what
might be called very plasant extra-curricular
activity, and provides an interest which ought
to be encouraged among graduates and under-.
graduates."

A MODEST PROPOSAL
A movement is afoot—a shocking, startling movement—to
solve the problem of overcrowded colleges by the simple expedient of refusing admission to women at coeducational schools!
It is argued by proponents of this plan that in today's world
a college education is absolutely essential for a man, while for
a woman it is merely a pleasant interlude between adolescence
and housewifery. There is simply not room enough for both men
and women in our overburdened colleges; therefore, in all fairness, women who have farless need of a degree than men, must
Yield their places.
Well sir, when I heard this drastic proposal,I was so shocked
that Isat right down and lit a Marlboro. I always sit right down
and light a Marlboro when Jam shocked. I also always sit right
down and light a Marlboro when I am not shocked. There is
no time, no condition, no mood, no estate when it isn't a source
of soul-deep gratification to settle back and have a full-flavored
smoke—Marlboro,the filtered cigarette with the unfiltered taste
— Marlboro, the jewel of cigarettes—Marlboro, the pinnacle of
the tobacconist's art—Marlboro, my comfort, haven, and snug
harbor.
Well sir, I sat smoking my Marlboro and thinking over the
shocking proposal to keep women out of coed schools,and hoping
fervently that another solution can be found. If the calamitous
(lay ever comes when women are banned from coed colleges, I
Will gnash my teeth and rend my garments and take to my bed
Without supper. Like any other Marlboro man,I love women.
I love the sight and sound of them, the cut of their jibs, their
beauty and grace, their cunning little spitcurls, their sleek
dimples, their middy blouses, their aura and effluvium. Moreover, I freely admit that when it comes to brainpower, they can
give the average man cards and spades and big casino too. It
would be a shame, a disgrace and a catastrophe to keep these
beautiful, intelligent creatures out of college.
However, it is always wise in time of fair weather to prepare
for foul. What if the advocates of keeping women out of college
begin to gather strength? We who abhor this fiendish plan must
be ready with a substitute...and it just so happens I have
one—and a mighty ingenious little plan it is, if I say so myself.
Granted that classroom seats are in short supply,and granted
that men need degrees more than women,it is still not necessary
to bar women from college. Let them go to college but—here is
the beauty part of my plan—don't let them go to class!

JACK SAVED HIS COMPANY $10,000
ON HIS FIRST ASSIGNMENT
While Jack Trabert was in college he had
some definite career ideas. He knew what he
wanted—a job with a payoff for good judgment
and hard work.
With a B.S. in Business Administration from
the University of Nebraska, Jack knew he could
look in many directions. And he did. He talked
to 20 companies. And then in August, 1957,
joined Northwestern Bell, in Omaha, Nebraska.
His chance to show what he could do was
not long in coming. On his first assignment Jack
came up with answers that made it possible to
handle long distance calls made at night in the
Omaha area with less force and equipment than
was needed under the old system. This resulted
in a $10,000 annual saving.
•
Next, Jack worked on a training and devel-

opment program for "mark sensing"—a new
method for mechanized processing of long distance charges.
Today, Jack has an important role in planning and developing telephone facilities to keep
pace with Omaha's ever-increasing need for long
distance services.
Jack puts it this way—"If a guy can keep
his average up, there are places to go in this
outfit. A man doesn't have to wait around for
opportunity to knock—he has all he can handle
right from the start."
If you want a job in which you're given a chance
to show your stuff, and held strictly accountable for
your decisions, right from the start—then you'll
want to visit your Placement Office for literature
and additional information.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 11, 1960

Week-Long Drive
To Stress Equality
Of Opportunity
The Baltimore Urban League
Vi11 sponsor an Equal Opportunities Week with the cooperation
of 21 other civic organizations
Including the Junior Bar association, the Junior League and the
Department of Education.

NEWS-LETTER

There will be discussions on
radio, television, in churches, and
in schools. An essay contest and
a poster contest will also be held
in conjunction with the week.
The culmination of the week's
activity will be a two part symposium in Levering Hall on
Saturday, November 19. The first
section will feature a talk on
"Figure in the Business World"
by Robert W. Dowling. Mr. Dowling will discuss the efforts to
achieve equal opportunities in

the business world.
The second part of the symposium will be devoted to the
legal aspect of equal opportunities in the business world. This
talk will be presented by Spottswood Robinson III, Dean of
Howard University School of
Law. A panel of lawyers will
participate in the discussion.
Members of the panel include
Charles Harris, Donald Schaffer,
Robert Watts, Herbert O'Connor
Jr., and Edward Dandridge.

By MATT CRENSON
The Emerson Hotel's WJZ-TV
headquarters was not exactly a
beehive of political activity last
Tuesday night as the television
station's personnel far outnumbered political partisans for a
good part of the evening. The
mood of those Democrats who
were present changed from one
of optimistic expectancy, to pressimism, to calm assurance.
Underlying the changes in temperament was a type of indifference characteristic of the Free

State.
Johns Hopkins' own Dr: Clarence Long, professor of political
economy and sometime candidate for the U.S. Senate, was
on hand to analyze the election
returns as they were received
over UPI teletype machines. Dr.
Long was at first reluctant to
make any definite predictions,
but as the night wore on and
the number of Democratic supporters on the premises become
greater, he grew more confident
in his prognostications. Dr. Long
gave Kennedy the election and
Predicted that the Democrats be
victorious in all state Congressional races except for the one
in the 6th district.
Among the onlookers in the
Emerson ballroom were two
gentlemen from the New Delhi
Medical School who seemed puzzled at the place of electronic
brains and the chattering teletype machines in the democratic
process. They compared the
quick coverage of the presidential race in the United States
with Indian elections in which
final results are sometimes not
politicos available for months.

Jays Vs. Devils In IVLA Homestretch
RootersFace DrexelIn Do OrDie Contest
Saturday's Game
Seen Is A Must
For Title Hopes
The Johns Hopkins soccer
team upped its season record to
672 during the last week in
games against the Shoremen of
Washington College, and the
Terrapins of Maryland.
In a game played last Saturday at Homewood, the Blue met
Washington College, possessors
01 a 6-3 record for the Fall.
Hopkins entered the game with
a 5-1 slate and the knowledge
that they must win to keep their
hopes alive for victory in the
Middle Atlantic Southern Division,
,The • weather was cold, and
gray, and that is the way the
game looked from the opening
Whistle. A slow starting team
all season, the Jays for once
reversed the trend and started
fast. Dominating the game for
Much of the first half; the Homewoodians kept control of the
ball and worked it around to set
up their scoring thrusts. Twice
in the first two quarters Hopkins players missed good chances,
and were forced to leave the
field at halftime in a 0-0 tie.
Fear of Washington's_ proven
comeback ability was in the air
at the start of the second-half,
and the drizzle that was falling
had everybody leery as the ball
Slithered merrily around the
field. Hopkins was imbued with
the will to win, however, and
Just before the end of the third
quarter Don Evenson scored unassisted. Going into the fourth
quarter the Blue led, 1-0.

Jays' Winning Wedge
Wrecks Swarthmore ,
By IRV NATHAN, Ass't Sports Editor
The "big-time" college athlete, particularly the football
player, is a strange breed.
He is usually maligned as being a dunce, majoring
in basketweaving, accepted (or bought) by the school to
bring fame and fortune to the institution. He is depicted
as being only a little short of a paid professional and is
usually thought of as being the beneficiary of both large
and small favors from professors, administrators, and
fellow students.
He is delineated as a mammoth brute hardly able to
pronounce the name of the university. He is the brunt of
rumors concerning such illegal practices as "red-shirting"
(playing for more than four years) and bribery.
In short, he is not even considered a student, but
rather a pariah who is well-reimbursed for his services.
At Hopkins, a "small-time" grid school, a footballplaying student iS not the recipient of special favors
and there are few, if any, rumors circulated, because no
one talks about him. The question at hand, then, is why
do these twenty-eight bruisers spend every week-day
afternoon knocking heads, and every Saturday defending
the well-deserved titles they captured last season.
Loyalty and a sense of deep pride are the prime
ingredients for a well-knit squad, and the Blue Jay varsity
pigskinners are a well-knit squad. Statistics- produced in
a recent issue of Sports Illustrated proved that college
athletes were receiving slightly better positions in the
business world than their merely academic classmates. It
is the considered opinion here that this loyalty and pride
are aslo fundamental requisites for success with any firm
or organization. And these devoted boys have this pride
and loyalty for the team and for the Johns Hopkins Universal.
It looked like Maryland was just too good for them
but despite the lopsided score the Varsity Soccermen
hung in all the way. They fought hard and hustled to the
last minute. Maryland had to work hard for those goals
and there were probably plenty terrapins rubbing their
black and blue marks on the way home.

Johns Hopkins varsity football
contingent, fresh from a convincing conquest of Swarthmore
last week, will entertain Mid-Atlantic opponent Dickinson in the
last home game of the campaign
tomorrow afternoon.
With the inside track on the
southern part of the Middle-atlantic championship, the Blue
Jay gridders face two must
games, this one and the encounter with Western Maryland
one week hence.
Dickinson comes in with an
unimpressive record for this
Homecoming weekend, but most
grid mentors will tell you it's
these "lowly" teams that bring
off the biggest upsets and spoil
the dreams of many a title contender.
Though the Red Devils have
posted but a 1-5 record for the
season, they boast backfield experience and the depth which the
Jays lack. Hopkins will outweigh
their Pennsylvania opponent by
five pounds down the line but
the likes of Center Don Fields
and Tackle Jim Wagner should
provide a stern test for the Jay
forward wall.
Running out of a varied offense off a split "T" formation,
Dickinson should have its major
problem in the line where they
will be missing the services of
Tackle Dave Morrissey, who was
a real "headache" for Hopkins in
the clash last year.
Last Saturday, the Jays bested
a determined Swarthmore aggregation to the tune of 21-12.
Using only five plays, primarily
a fullback wedge, the Jays ran
over and through Garnet lineman, running its seasonal log to
5-1-1.
Unbeaten and united in Middle-Atlantic competition, the
Jays are one-half game ahead of
Pennsylvania Military College
who are presently sporting a
5-1-0 mark. In the two conference games remaining, PMC

will go up against winless
Swarthmore and power-laden
Lebanon Valley. Though very
deep and powerful, the Lebanon
Valley gridders just eeked out
a win over Hopkins' for Dickinson, earlier in the year.
Following PMC in the southern
division are Ursinus (3:3-0),
Western
Maryland
(1-2-0),
Dickinson (1-4-0), Swarthmore
(0-3-0), Drexel (0-5-0), and
Haverford (0-5-0). Ineligible for
the league crown are Franklin
and Marshall (1-1-0) and West
Chester (no games).
Jay Coach Wilson Fewster
lauded all the gridders for what
he called "a real outstanding
team effort" in the Swarthmore
battle. He added that it has been
this attidue of playing for the
team and not for themselves that
has garnered the impressive record the Jays have accumulated.
A large Homecoming crowd is
expected to be on hand for the
2:00 kickoff. Another large turnout is anticipated for the Western Maryland game next week.

Jays fired a 1378 out of possible
1500, 19 points higher than any
of last year's scores. The Delaware team shot a 1276.
Team captain John Belt was
JHU's top scorer with a 96-93-92,
for a total Of 281. Also scoring
strongly for the Blue Jays were
Gordon Hair with a 279, Dan
Searing shooting 277, Carl Born
with a 272, and Tito del Amo,
who shot 269. Bob Steinhauer,
first for the University, of Delaware, shot a 261.
Following the match with Gettysburg, the rifle team will host
Morgan State Teachers College,
Friday, November 18. Also in addition to its regular schedule, the
riflemen will aim their barrels in
an attempt to bag the Hearst
Trophy.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 11, 1960

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE ELEVEN

Frosh Footballers End Maryland Swamps Soccermen
Season Vs.Gettysburg For 1st Jay Shutout In 2 Years
By TED PARLETTE
Today, the freshmen football
season for Hopkins comes to an
end with the yearling Jays taking on Gettysburg College across
the border in Pennsylvania. After
a very fine job last week in holding a big B.J.C. group to only
two touchdowns, the team has
an even bigger task cut out for
them this week.
In containing B.J.C.'s powerful
single-wing attack, Hopkins allowed but two touchdowns via
the ground route, the other two
coming as opportunity plays on
a kickoff and a poor punt. Two
Of these TDs were called back
because of penalties against
B.J.C., however. Bearing special
notice on defense were Steve
Erlanger who was outstanding
as a defensive end, and Joe Hahn
and Chuck Aronhalt who shared
top tackle honors with 5 apiece.
The rest of the forward wall
also deserves a vote of confidence
for their part in containing their
Much bigger and heavier opponents.
Directing the offense, which
gained more yardage than in

any previous outing this year,
was quarterback Tom Tropp.
Rushing, Hopkins piled up 104
yards to Baltimore Junior College's 172. A large part of this
yardage, in fact 56 yards of it,
belonged to halfback John Heller
who averaged 5.6 yards per carry. Fullback Walt Divers was
second with an average of 3.5'
It was a good day all around for
the freshman team.
Gettysburg, while not so big as
B.J.C., is undoubtedly a stronger
team, having the experience of
13 high school captains or cocaptains on their squad. In the
past two seasons.at Hopkins, the
frosh footballers have lost only
One game each. Both of these
have been to Gettysburg outfits
like this year's. This suffices to
show it's going to be a tough
game, especially for Hopkins.
There were several odd punt
plays in the game, both involving
kicker Chuck Aronhalt. In the
first of these, a short kick was
caught by the wind and blown
back to the home five-yard line
where a Baltimore Junior College
lineman scooped it up and carried the pigskin to pay dirt.

(Continued from Page 9)
The last quarter was a fingernail biter all the way as first
the Jays, and then Washington,
fired away at each others' goalies.
Bob Keane, JHU netminder, successfully repulsed all W.C. scoring efforts and Hopkins won its
second shutout in a row.

from College Park methodically
deflated Hopkins hope of pulling off one of the upsets of the
year. Scoring in every period,
and with inside right Cliff Krug
netting five, the Marylanders
controlled the game throughout,

and at will.
With two games remaining,
against Drexel here on Saturday
at noon, and Western Maryland
away Nov. 19, the Bluejays still
have an outside chance for the
Middle Atlantic Southern crown.

The victory over Washington
lifted the Jays Middle Atlantic
mark to 4-1, with two games remaining. Hopkins is undefeated
in Mason-Dixon play, with a 3-0
mark, but are ineligible for the
title as they do not play enough
games.
Wednesday saw the Homewoodians play host to the only
non-league opponent on their
schedule, perenially powerful
Maryland.
The Jays were outclassed from
the beginning as Maryland's
combination of speed, skill,
hustle„ and general superiority
sent the home team down to
their worst defeat since 1956's
beating by the same team, and
same score, 7-0. The Terrapins
